Award.AwardTitle: Mechanism and Specificity of DNA Repair Dealkylases

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Genomic DNA undergoes spontaneous chemical modification (alkylation) whereby cellular or environmental reactive chemicals alter its structure and information content; therefore, cells require DNA repair pathways to detect and counteract these deleterious changes. This research will characterize the mechanism and specificity of a newly discovered pathway called direct repair in which a DNA repair dealkylase restores the correct nucleotide via a reaction involving multiple steps. By integrating trainees at all levels into the project, the PI will prepare individuals for future careers in STEM-related fields. Students will receive interdisciplinary training in genetic, biochemical, and biophysical techniques while gaining specific expertise in protein and nucleic acid biochemistry. A continued focus will be on recruiting students from underrepresented groups and outreach to the community, from elementary school all the way up to medical school, to incite a passion for basic sciences and to foster a diverse scientific community.

The project identifies ALKB and ALKBH2 as representative examples of a broad superfamily of DNA repair oxidative dealkylases and addresses important unanswered questions about how these enzymes search for lesions in DNA, distinguish repair substrates from non-substrates, and maintain specificity for a broad range of substrates that complement other known DNA repair pathways. The central hypothesis is that the mechanism of ALKB enzymes has parallels to independently evolved DNA glycosylases that use different chemistry and different structural folds to overcome similar biological and physical challenges. The research will apply a combined approach of enzymology, transient kinetics, structure/function analysis, kinetic modeling, and genetics to understand the mechanisms by which ALKB and ALKBH2 find and repair DNA damage.

This project is funded jointly by the Genetic Mechanisms Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences in the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Spontaneous alkylation of genomic DNA is unavoidable and occurs as a consequence of normal metabolism and upon exposure to environmental carcinogens. The burden of alkylation damage is increased by a wide variety of biological stresses, including cancer. We have been investigating the evolutionary mechanisms by which all life forms deal with alkylation damage to prevent cell death or mutagenesis. This funding period has focused on the specificity and mechanism of the direct repair pathway and contrasts it with the better understood base excision repair pathway for detecting and correcting DNA alkylation events. 

Intellectual merit: This award resulted in 3 primary publications that have revised the prevailing models for repair of many ubiquitous forms of DNA damage. The paradigm was shifted as we disproved the central model for how direct repair enzymes, which use molecular oxygen and 2-oxoglutarate to remove unwanted alkyl adducts from DNA, are conserved across all eukaryotes. We demonstrated that in budding yeast, the direct repair pathway has been lost and it has been compensated for by expanded capabilities of the base excision repair pathway. In retrospect, this insight explains many of the unique features of alkylation repair in yeast and the reliance of this organism on the single alkylation repair glycosylase, Mag1. Furthermore, our work opens up new questions regarding the role of base excision repair as a protector of both exogenous and endogenous DNA damage. Our quantitative and systematic study of the bacterial AlkB enzyme has uncovered shortcomings in the literature and provided new approaches to studying DNA repair catalyzed by AlkB family enzymes. We report that E. coli AlkB, the prototypical direct repair enzyme, is orders of magnitude more active than previously described and we provide a blueprint for study of substrate specificity for the broader family of AlkB homologs, including the two human homologs responsible for DNA repair. These unprecedented findings provide a new framework to more accurately decipher the role of direct repair pathways relative to other known DNA repair pathways. In recent unpublished work this foundation has led to new findings regarding the differences in specificity among homologous direct repair enzymes and some fundamental commonalities in mechanisms of base excision repair and direct alkylation repair.

Broader impact: Beyond the scientific progress, this award provided for the training of numerous individuals in biochemical and genetic approaches to understanding life. Over the duration of the funding, 4 undergraduate students, 4 graduate students, 1 postdoctoral fellow and two research scientists directly received full or partial financial support. Of these 11 individuals, spanning multiple years, 6 were women, 5 were men, and 5 out of the 11 belong to ethnic groups who are underrepresented in the sciences (URM). These former trainees have gone on to graduate school in top programs, have been employed as STEM teachers, have entered medical school, or are employed in the biotech industry or academia. The diversity of outcomes speaks to the general value of training in this scientific discipline. Some of these individuals received full stipend support from the award and others were able to cover part of their support by successfully competing for independent financial support, including NIH-funded training fellowships, the Summer Research Opportunities Program at the University of Michigan, and the NSF-funded interdisciplinary REU in the Structure and Function of Proteins at the University of Michigan.
